context: In a previous study, we did not find any increase in other exhaled markers of airway inflammation and/or oxidative stress (i.e., NO, CO, and nitrite) after ozone exposure. This indicates that 8-isoprostane may be a more sensitive exhaled marker of ozone-induced oxidant damage. Other authors did not find any correlation between indices of airway inflammation and the decrease in lung function due to ozone. Although we did not measure 8-isoprostane immediately after ozone exposure, we observed a similar lack of correlation between the concentration of this compound in EBC and lung function at 4 h postexposure. At this time point, FEV1 and FVC values had returned to pre-exposure levels, whereas breath condensate 8-isoprostane was elevated compared with pre-exposure values, indicating that an ozone-induced increase in oxidative stress in the airways is more persistent than the effects on lung function. We were unable to assess the effects of ozone on lung inflammation after 4 h from a single exposure and at different time points within 4 h. Further research is needed to study these effects.
